item.title: The sound of photosynthesis
item.dc:creator: David Colliaux
item.description:
The photosynthetic electron transport chain

Plants are converting CO_2 into O_2 and glucose via light energy through photosynthesis. This process is decomposed into : first the light reaction converting light energy into chemical energy (ATP), then the dark reaction responsible for the assimilation of CO into glucose. We talk here about the first part which consist in a cascade of oxydo-reduction reaction called the photosynthetic electron transport chain (PETC).

Photons hitting the antennas attached to the membrane of the chloroplasts are absorbed and create a flow of electrons through the chain but a small portion of the energy is re-emitted through the chlorophyll fluorescence. It is possible to measure this fluorescence in response to light stimulation to probe the PETC and actually several locations in the PETC can be probed through this technique: the reactions centers (P700) and the various redox pools (plastocyanine PC, or ferredoxin Fd) visible on the figure below.

Sonification of the PETC

It is possible to study such non-linear systems by sinewave stimulation and tracking harmonics in the response spectrum, higher harmonics being indicative of non-linearities in the system. Ladislav Nedbal in his talk at the DREAM workshop 2025 suggested, from visual inspection, that the waveform of the fluorescence he measured in response to oscillating light is similar to that of a saxophone.

This sounded interesting to me so I decided to listen to the timber of the PETC through sonification of the various signals recorded in the study of Yuxi Niu and al. (Niu et al. 2023) on Arabidopsis thaliana plants exposed to fluctuating light.

For each of the observables (Light, Chlorohyll Fluorescence, PC, Fd and P700), I collected the cleaned waveform where only the first 4 harmonics were kept at various frequencies. I then rescaled the timeseries to a 440Hz signal and added a Hanning window to give a simple dynamics envelope.

You can hear the result below. Except for the Light signal which is always a pure sine wave, the timber is quite different depending on the frequency…That’s how photosynthesis sounds!
